dt: {bc}the mixture of invisible odorless tasteless gases (such as nitrogen and oxygen) that surrounds the earth
{bc}the equivalent mix of gases on another planet
{bc}the medium of transmission of radio waves
{bc}the look, appearance, or bearing of a person especially as expressive of some personal quality or emotion {bc}{sx|demeanor||}
usually used in the phrases {it}into thin air{/it} and {it}out of thin air{/it}

dt.t: … nor did any of them seem to have noticed that six people had just melted {wi}into thin air{/wi} in front of them.
… jobs can't just be created {wi}out of thin air{/wi}.

dt: {bc}the chief voice part or melody in choral music
{bc}an accompanied song or melody in usually strophic form
{bc}a football offense utilizing primarily the forward pass

dt.t: Trailing by 20 points, the team took to the {wi}air{/wi}.

dt: {bc}the height achieved in performing an aerial maneuver
{bc}being felt or expressed by many people {bc}in wide circulation

dt.t: There was a sense of anticipation {wi}in the air{/wi}.
a question that's still {wi}up in the air{/wi}

pt: {sc}pose{/sc} {sc}air{/sc} {sc}airs{/sc} {sc}affectation{/sc} {sc}mannerism{/sc} mean an adopted way of speaking or behaving. {sc}pose{/sc} implies an attitude deliberately assumed in order to impress others.
{sc}air{/sc} may suggest natural acquirement through environment or way of life.
{sc}affectation{/sc} applies to a trick of speech or behavior that strikes the observer as insincere.
{sc}mannerism{/sc} applies to an acquired eccentricity that has become a habit.

pt.t: gesturing with a cigarette was her most noticeable {it}mannerism{/it}

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from Latin {it}aer{/it}, from Greek {it}aēr{/it} air
shortdef: the mixture of invisible odorless tasteless gases (such as nitrogen and oxygen) that surrounds the earth; also : the equivalent mix of gases on another planet

dt: {bc}to expose to the air for drying, purifying, or refreshing {bc}{sx|ventilate||}

dt.t: He opened the windows to {wi}air{/wi} out the room.

dt: {bc}to expose to public view or bring to public notice
{bc}to become exposed to the open air

dt.t: The blankets were left outside to {wi}air{/wi}.

pt: {sc}express{/sc} {sc}vent{/sc} {sc}utter{/sc} {sc}voice{/sc} {sc}broach{/sc} {sc}air{/sc} mean to make known what one thinks or feels. {sc}express{/sc} suggests an impulse to reveal in words, gestures, actions, or what one creates or produces.
{sc}vent{/sc} stresses a strong inner compulsion to express especially in words.
{sc}utter{/sc} implies the use of the voice not necessarily in articulate speech.
{sc}voice{/sc} does not necessarily imply vocal utterance but does imply expression or formulation in words.
{sc}broach{/sc} adds the implication of disclosing for the first time something long thought over or reserved for a suitable occasion.
{sc}air{/sc} implies an exposing or parading of one's views often in order to gain relief or sympathy or attention.

shortdef: to expose to the air for drying, purifying, or refreshing : ventilate —often used with out
to expose to public view or bring to public notice
to transmit by radio or television

dt: {bc}a shot that completely misses the rim and backboard

shortdef: a shot that completely misses the rim and backboard

dt: {bc}a military base chiefly for the operation of aircraft

shortdef: a military base chiefly for the operation of aircraft

dt: {bc}a soft, airtight plastic case that is designed to be inflated and used as a bed {bc}{sx|air mattress||}

dt.t: Modern {wi}air beds{/wi} which resemble a big mattress can be very good indeed. Buy an air pump.

shortdef: a soft, airtight plastic case that is designed to be inflated and used as a bed : air mattress

dt: {bc}a sac containing gas and especially air

dt.t: The float tube was an ingenious device built around an inner tube, featuring a seat and backrest created from an additional {wi}air bladder{/wi} in the nylon shell of the rig.

dt: {bc}a saclike organ present in most bony fishes which contains gas and especially oxygen and nitrogen and that serves chiefly to control buoyancy and in some primitive fish (such as the {d_link|lungfish|lungfish}) functions as an accessory respiratory organ

dt.t: Elasmobranchs lack the {wi}air bladder{/wi} that gives other fishes buoyancy, and their skeletons are made of light cartilage instead of bone.
Fish make sounds by clicking their teeth, blowing air, and drumming with special muscles against tuned inflated {wi}air bladders{/wi}.

dt: {bc}a gas- or air-filled vesicle in certain algae and aquatic plants (such as rockweed) that helps keep photosynthetic blades and fronds buoyant

dt.t: At the base of each frond is a small {wi}air bladder{/wi} that buoys the blade up to the surface, where it continues to grow while forming a dense canopy approximately 4 feet deep.

shortdef: a sac containing gas and especially air : such as

a saclike organ present in most bony fishes which contains gas and especially oxygen and nitrogen and that serves chiefly to control buoyancy and in some primitive fish (such as the lungfish) functions as an accessory respiratory organ —called also swim bladder
a gas- or air-filled vesicle in certain algae and aquatic plants (such as rockweed) that helps keep photosynthetic blades and fronds buoyant —called also pneumatocyst

dt: {bc}a brake operated by a piston driven by compressed air
{bc}a surface that may be projected into the airstream for increasing drag and lowering the speed of an airplane

shortdef: a brake operated by a piston driven by compressed air
a surface that may be projected into the airstream for increasing drag and lowering the speed of an airplane

dt: {bc}of, employing, or being an engine that requires air for combustion

shortdef: of, employing, or being an engine that requires air for combustion

shortdef: a commissioned officer in the British air force who ranks with a general in the army
